However, one thing which this post doesn't bring up(though one of the other comments does) but I feel is pretty important is the MC-152728 bugfix implemented in 1.21.4; sprinting while sneaking or crawling allows in my opinion some of the smoothest and most satisfying movement in Minecraft(the low regular speed but high speed boost from sprint jumping just feels really nice to do), and overall the removal of that option makes the game feel a lot clunkier with the fact that things like eating, sneaking and crawling now force you to stop sprinting while not making the game better in any way.
Yet another "bug fix" that has been long considered a feature by the community at large. Really hope Mojang/Microsoft actually listen to their community for once and actually reconsider this change.

Wanted to comment to outline the specifics of why the changes brought by the "patching" of MC-271065 are such a huge detriment to the game to a significant amount of people, as I haven't seen it described properly yet. 

The original bug report pertained exclusively to the ~41% speed increase when strafing while crouching/crawling etc. What however was not mention was the ~2.04% speed increase while running or walking normally on the ground/in air. For clarity, I will refer to the intentional utilising either of these speed increases for some purpose in game as "45ing", "45s" etc, as the common way they are used would be to look 45 degrees from where you want to go, then hold (w/s) + strafe the opposite way.

Although the 2.04% 45 boost while not crouching was not reported, the change that was made in 25w02a also eliminated this as a byproduct. The effects of removing sneak45ing on bridging have been spoken on plenty, and I have seen a proposed fix to this be increasing default sneak speed, however this is not a viable solution as it would leave regular 45ing relegated to the past, and so reverting the change is all around a more sensible solution. 

 45ing has been present in the game since at least the days of beta (probably earlier but I can't attest to that) and has been a staple of the game for thousands of players for over a decade. It is commonly utilised for example when players are running with speed 2, and provides a small assist to escape/chase down people. --{1/2}--

--{2/2}-- As well as this, you can see 45ing occasionally on display even in big Minecraft events like MCC or Blockwars, as players will sometimes use it during a racing game to go that little bit faster.

More important to me personally, this small increase is hugely important to the technical parkour community, who spend hundreds of hours on individual jumps/maps built with a heavy reliance on this mechanic. 25w02a renders a huge amount of parkour maps impossible, and every single previously "difficult" jump is now rendered impossible. Players will be forced to stay in an older version, or lose an incredible amount of depth that was previously present in the game.

Overall, I can acknowledge how MC-271065 seems like buggy behaviour, because in a way it is. However, it has been a staple of the game for 15 years, and is hugely important to tens of thousands of players. It has absolutely no negative impact on the playing experience of the average player, but add massive amounts of depth and complexity to the game for players who want to push the possibilities of what can be done within the game to its absolute limits. Making a change like this for the sake of "consistency" does not improve the average player's experience in any way, but it effectively uproots entire communities that have sunk countless hours into this game we all love. I beg that this change be reverted, and perhaps all "small" changes to base movement mechanics not be altered with such reckless abandon in future.

Calling MC-271065 and MC-241951 "bugs" just shows how out of touch Minecraft's developers are with their own player base. These mechanics have been a core part of the game for years. Removing them under the guise of "fixing bugs" is absurd.

It‚Äôs clear that this move is driven by the need to "align" Java and Bedrock, especially with issues like MCPE-152775 ("Sneaking sideways is slower on Bedrock than Java"). But this approach is damaging. Minecraft‚Äôs identity comes from its unique mechanics, and forcing these versions to be more alike for the sake of a unified experience is a poor excuse for ruining what makes Java special.

Stop trying to "fix" things that aren‚Äôt broken. Stripping these techniques away will break countless maps, disrupt established gameplay, and ultimately hurt the game.
The consequences of these bugfixes are overblown. Adding a 40% speed buff to base sneaking speed would make majority of casual players happy without reintroducing broken behaviour.

The diagonal movement is unintuitive when compared to reality, and normal physics. I still feel that it should be kept how it is, due to the amount of strategy built around this being the way the game works, most notably bridging. The fall damage change, however, is different. There's no theoretically correct number fall damage should start at (that wasn't chosen by the game designers). This is a significant change that causes vastly more accumulation of fall damage, and therefore annoyance, over time. Due to how short these distances in blocks are, a change from 3 blocks + 1 jump to 2 blocks + 1 jump is about a 25% alteration, which is hugely significant. I've tried it out in a normal survival context and it felt worse to play. Every time I took damage after jumping off a 2 block ledge, I noticed. I'm sure over time I'd stop noticing and it'd become more of a background irritation, but still, I can't remember any change made any time recently that I've thought actually made the game noticeably worse. I always feel irritated when people get annoyed at the latest features simply because they dislike them or view them through a negative lens, but I agree that this causes too much harm to be worth the benefits.

I never even knew these were bugs, I thought they were a part of Minecraft movement physics. I think it's super cool that players can take these minor details of the game and ever-so-slightly improve their gameplay quality, and it pushes the limits of what Minecraft players can achieve. 45 strafing... PvP movement... and not only in the competitive scene... sprint-crouch-jumping to make cool obstacles in SMPs with friends and just playing around with mechanics in a single player world. All of this has been so ingrained in Minecraft gameplay, and it would in my opinion be detrimental to all gameplay, whether it's 1.8 PvP, 1.20 parkour, or casual survival Minecraft. It's like setting up your hotkeys 10 years ago, so used to pressing R to sprint instead of double-tapping W. And then you just change that R key to T. Not a major change (only one key apart), but completely changes the entire gameplay for players.

I hope this post blows up and these changes don't get implemented. Thank you 3rasmian for the initiative.

I know the majority of comments may be talking about this change in the context of the competitive Minecraft scene, so I won't mention any more about that. However, as a mostly survival player, diagonal crouch bridging and diagonal sprinting are very important to me. Diagonal crouch bridging is great for bridging across lava lakes, and Diagonal Sprinting is something I do pretty much unconsciously as I look at the world around me whenever I am traveling through the Overworld. I understand this change is being implemented for parity with Minecraft Bedrock, but it would be much better if diagonal sprinting and crouching were added to Bedrock instead of taking away such fundamental features from Java Minecraft. I'm looking forward to a positive response to this petition, along with potentially millions of others that have also been playing 10+ years on Java. 

 

-Minecraft Java Player since 2009

Reminder that the diagonal movement being the square root of [normal straight movement speed^2 + side movement speed^2] just means that the game used Pythagorean Theorem in the code from day 1. That can't be a bug, that's intentional. Bugs *aren't* intentional. It was *SUPOSED* to be this way.

Responding to some common arguments for this suggestion:

- "This puts you in a disadvantage"
No, because it is balanced by the fact those changes aren't personal to YOU and opponent not having this either puts you both in an equal position again where exploits don't gain your extra mobility.

- "Some of the hardest parkour jumps are now impossible"
Duh. Parkour tests limits within the engine, human mind, reaction time and if you wanna make it harder you'd wanna compact it even more to the point where even an accidental 0.000000000001% change in a singular value would break it completely. They were created with this in mind and specifically for these purposes. Do you know how many older parkour courses "broke" when Mojang added the ability to sprint in b1.8? But surprise surprise, parkour adapted. It's not some new terrifying concept, it's a well-known thing in the parkour community and if you were really part of it you would know this.

Some jumps are broken, they'll adapt and be fixed, just like redstone is when there comes an improvement to game performance. I only agree with your "short term" argument here.

This is simply a horrendous change. I have played minecraft on and off since the very earliest versions were available to play. This movement is simply apart of minecraft. Movement is one of the most significant ways players interact with a game from a first person perspective. To change a movement style that people enjoy and that the meta has evolved around for the last 15 years is not just negligent, it's absolutely incompetent and malicious.

To spell this out further:

1. It's negligent because it utterly disregards the experience and needs of the community at large, as well as the building and parkour communities in particular

2. It's incompetent because changing a movement that has been established for over 15 years is not something to do on a whim, especially if it doesn't break the game, and you don't do it without extensive investigation as to whether it's even necessary in the first place. Even if somehow it 'broke' the game (WHICH IT DOES NOT), the only competent move would be to reimplement it in a way that doesn't break the game to satisfy all minecraft players, especially the parkour and builder communities.

3. It's malicious because it ruins one of the fundamental aspect for how all minecraft players interact with the world, and completely destroys the established parkour community meta, and will make building far more tedious for everyone.

This is a horrid change, and must be reversed if Mojang does not want to be deemed Negligent, Incompetent and Malicious!

Mojang, this "bug" has been in the game for 15 years, obviously if a bug would exist for such a long time, players will count it as a feature. This is going to hurt parkour, speedbriding and pvp communities in Minecraft. Parkour players have spent countless hours perfecting their 45 strafes to make before impossible jumps possible. Ang parkour maps made in this timeframe of 15 years utilizing the use of 45 strafes would be now impossible to beat. Speedbriding is a technique where players require precise timings to place their blocks while shifting, a 40% speed decrease in that is going to be brutal to those who generally play competitive games using briding like bedwars and skywars. For those who spent time perfecting their aim with diagonal moving to get just a little bit more knockback would end. Whether this change gets implemented in the final version or not, its going to be insignificant to an average survival player but will hurt the more competitive side of the game. So when a change is just a net loss for the game, I strictly believe it should not be implemented. On top of all that its not a gamebreaking exploit or something and many games purposefully implement it too. I hope you learned at least something from 1.9 update.

I can only guess that this is some misguided attempt at feature parity with Bedrock edition, probably a directive that Microsoft is pushing on Mojang. They need to realize that if "feature parity" means making Java Edition worse, then we don't want it. The "unrealistic" movement difference does nothing but make the game feel better. If it's really that much of a problem for controllers, then have the game detect input method and adjust movement based on that, although even games with controllers have had this sort of thing still be possible without issue (like in most Halo games up until at least Reach (if not later), when holding a heavy weapon that you ripped off of a tripod). Yeah, it's not intended, but it's *fine* and it adds depth to the gameplay. This doesn't just affect competitive players, it affects everyone by removing a cool trick that's fun to use and which could easily be considered an originally-unintended feature instead of a bug.

Also, on a related note, the fall damage height change is absurd. Why should we *constantly* be taking chip damage and having our hunger bars drained? Do you think that makes the game more fun somehow? There have been other changes made to movement recently as well, such as the "sprint sneak" technique being made impossible in a recent main update (which also made movement with an elytra on become incredibly clunky in certain situations). Why? It existed for nearly a *decade* and made the game better and made the game more appealing.

* Removal of 45-Degree Strafing: This mechanic has been integral to Minecraft movement for years, allowing for precise and skillful maneuvering. Its removal undermines established techniques in:
    * Parkour: 45-degree strafing allows for accurate jumps and fluid movement across complex obstacle courses. Its removal will drastically increase the difficulty of existing parkour maps and limit future map design.
    * Speed Bridging: Efficient and competitive speed bridging relies heavily on precise strafing. Removing this mechanic will severely hinder speedrunners and potentially make certain bridging techniques impossible.
    * Ace Race: While less crucial than in parkour or speed bridging, 45-degree strafing provides players with more control during flight, allowing for tighter turns and more strategic navigation.
    * PvP Combat: Strafing is a fundamental aspect of PvP, allowing players to dodge attacks and outmaneuver opponents. Its removal will simplify combat and potentially make it less skill-based.

* Fall Damage After Two Blocks: While seemingly minor, this change significantly impacts the flow of movement and introduces unnecessary punishment for small drops. It will hinder exploration and make traversing the world feel clunkier and more restrictive

This "bug" is in the same class as MC-152728, both "bugs" improve movement and add depth to the game. Several players made use of both regularly. The thing is removing sneak sprinting and adding sprint interrupting actions was bad enough, but this change enters the territory of affecting a HUGE segment of the player base. We're talking about changes that affect building, PVP, and destroy parkour courses.

"Fixing" MC-152728 was a minor annoyance for casuals and ruined legitimate strategies that more hardcore players used to great effect.

However, this "bug" affects a far larger portion of the player base as it impacts builders. I can tell you right now, this "bug" was NOT on most people's radar as a "problem needing to be fixed." Most players probably used it without realizing it. I don't know about you, but when building large structures, my natural reaction when placing blocks is to hold shift, S, and a strafe key. I do this on all of my rooves and a sizeable chunk of my walls when building. So, what this "fix" really does is make a slow task even slower.

Parkour courses actually take the blunt of both of these "fixes" as several movement options and as a result ENTIRE courses may no longer possible in newer versions. You could get to a part of a course and suddenly there's an impossible move that you need to perform but can no longer perform. It's not like you can just fix a broken course either, change 1 block and the entire course might need to be totally rebuilt.

Reposting because the other thread got deleted:

I agree with reverting the copper bulb to the behaviour it was originally introduced with. It was popular among the community, and provided a new functionality for more advanced and creative players to create new things without impacting how most players will interact with the bulb (using a lever or button to toggle it).

I can see how the other change introduced this week (to crafters) could be necessary for balance and to prevent exploitation, but this change cannot be justified this way. It is already a different class of functionality to existing redstone, and does not need to behave like them. Using this reasoning, very little would be added to the game today simply because it wasn't similar enough to what came before it.
To make both sides happy,  just put a toggle in the settings to choose how you want it.

We have other blocks that already have a 2gt delay. Repeaters, note blocks and so forth. We do not need another block with a 2 gt delay. The 1 gt delay worked well as it allowed for finer timing of redstone circuitry without resorting to hacky and likely lag inducing workarounds to achieve this finer level of control. More over the reduction in complexity this block provides could also serve to aid in bridging the gap between java and bedrock Redstone. Since you would reduce your reliance on hacky workarounds that could end up being very implementation specific. 

 

All and all, this nerf is a mistake and should either be reverted or this functionality should be given to another block if this change was due to a fear of the bulb having too many uses. I do remind you that comparators exist.
Having a 1 tick delay in one block is very a very useful feature. Removing it from the game serves no purpose.
It was an attended feature the first time and it became a very love feature, I think it just makes sense to revert it back to its original text speed.

Copper Bulbs now have no delay (like a trapdoor) instead of 1 game tick of delay (1/2 a redstone tick) for turning on/off. This means comparators and observers now activate 2gt after the Bulb is un/powered rather than 3gt.

Some reasons why 1gt delay is good:

  • It's the most compact way to make odd gt delay
  • it creates more diversity in redstone components; it doesn't behave like a hopper or trapdoor or noteblock when using an observer on it

Some reasons why no delay is good:

  • Its more united with the other redstone components that all have even delay, so it's easier to synchronize, and more understandable for novice redstoners.
  • Copper Bulb circuits are faster
  • Copper Bulb now responds to 0-tick pulses, and can even be toggled multiple times in the same tick. This opens up some interesting new applications.

Both ways have their pros, and people are going to be unsatisfied if either way is chosen. So why settle for just one way or the other? We can have a system where the oxidation level corresponds to delay:
No Corrosion - no delay
Exposed - 1 game tick delay
Weathered - 2 game ticks of delay
Oxidized - 3 game ticks of delay

A change like this will satisfy both groups of people. It's also cool in a lore sense - older redstone circuits work slower if not waxed. Not to mention it expands the use cases of the copper bulb with 2gt and 3gt delay possible. It also brings the copper bulb closer to the identity of copper as a material with the oxidation mechanic.

Strongly disagree with the idea that the copper bulb should be one-tick delayed because "I want it". Whether or not a 1-tick delay is useful in general isn't really relevant to whether the copper bulb should have it or not. The function of a copper bulb is to be a toggleable light source. For manual interaction and using it for that purpose in redstone, 0-tick delay is a better implementation. 1-tick delay created a weird, unnatural delay when interacting normally with the block and was nothing but a decrease in performance for redstone circuits that used the toggle property.

A potential solution for that could be different delays depending on oxidation state, but I don't really think that's a good idea because then creating a stable redstone device with copper bulbs would require you to make sure all copper bulbs are waxed, which is not an easily visible property.
I've not seen any valid reason why this was even accepted and pushed as a bug, as it is clearly a new and unique block with new properties to explore.

Alternatively, have each state of the copper bulb have a different delay to match with the fact that it appears to be "decaying". Regardless, the 1 tick delay was revolutionary for the redstone community. It should stay in the game. Something that the community was so excited for should not be needlessly removed.

I have two points to bring up. First, I cannot understand why they claim that the copper bulb was reverted for the sake of consistency. No one wants new features that are the same as old features.

Second, if they are going to remove the one tick delay, it would make sense for the following reason: using lots of copper bulbs creates light updates which can cause some lag. For that reason I can see why they might want it to be less useful in redstone.

The issue here is that the redstone community was really hyped because of the one tick delay and taking it away after receiving lots of positive feedback is strange and caused a lot of disappointment.

To make up for this mistake, I suggest one of three changes is made:
First, they could simply revert the copper bulb to how it was in the first snapshot. (It was great back then)
Second, they could revert the copper bulb and somehow make it possible to use it in redstone without causing light updates.
Third, if they aren't going to bring back the one tick delay, at least add a new component that has this functionality (maybe a copper repeater?) Many players were very excited about the one tick delay and it's introduction into the game would definitely have caused a surge in activity within the redstone community and possibly for all types of players.

We want to be heard, so prove that you can hear us. Minecraft isn't just some kids game where the players don't have an opinion

Absolutely this is something that should be reverted. Just looking at the community explosion due to the initial iteration of the copper bulb (and crafter) was exciting and brought a lot of hype to the update. Changing it only diminishes that impact.

As far as I can tell, having odd tick delays is only a benefit to the introduction of the block as a whole. It doesn't impede the primary functions of the block (lighting and a t flip flop), and instead only adds more use for the more technical players. One tick of delay is not noticeable in any casual or building capacity and will not impact the average user experience negatively or in a way that causes confusion.

Having blocks that are unique creates new opportunities and fun ways to experiment and play the game. Changing it to be the same as other blocks removes this creativity with game mechanics (something I have issue with the crafter changes as well, but on a lesser scale).

Also for the comments that are saying that Minecraft Bedrock only runs on 10 game ticks per second, and that is why Mojang removed the 1 tick delay mechanic from java, you aren't entirely wrong. Minecraft Bedrock does run on 20 game ticks per second like Java, but only updates redstone every redstone tick, not every game tick. This means that 1 gametick delays are completely impossible in Bedrock edition. The old Blast Protection was far superior to the current reworked version because it provided a much more consistent and reliable experience for players. In the past, the knockback reduction from Blast Protection was more effective, ensuring that players could stay on their feet during combat or while navigating explosive situations, such as creeper blasts or TNT. This stability was crucial for survival, especially in high-risk environments like PvP or challenging survival gameplay. With the current rework, however, the knockback reduction stacking is inconsistent, leaving players vulnerable at critical moments when they need it the most. The change diminishes the strategic value of the enchantment, making it feel more like a passive buff rather than a crucial tool for mitigating explosive threats. Many players enjoyed the old system because it offered a clear and dependable advantage, and the new system fails to provide the same level of certainty, causing frustration for those who rely on it in difficult scenarios. Reverting to the old Blast Protection would restore balance and ensure that players can continue to face explosions with confidence.

I completely agree that the current stacking mechanic for Blast Protection needs reconsideration. While the intention might have been to provide stronger defensive options, completely negating knockback from explosions creates an unintended gameplay imbalance. The lack of knockback makes surviving explosions easier but also removes an important element of positioning and damage mitigation. This is particularly frustrating in PvP and Survival modes, where explosions are a key factor in combat strategy.

Mojang has shown they‚Äôre willing to listen to community feedback, as seen with the reversion of the previous enchantment nerfs. A balanced approach‚Äîperhaps capping the knockback reduction at a reasonable level instead of outright negating it‚Äîwould be a much better solution. Hopefully, they take this into account in the next update!"**

This comment acknowledges the issue, provides a logical argument, and encourages Mojang to implement a balanced fix. Let me know if you want any adjustments!

The recent change allowing Blast Protection‚Äôs knockback reduction to stack in Minecraft 1.21 creates significant gameplay issues that warrant reconsideration. While Mojang reverted previous nerfs to protection enchantments, this mechanic remains problematic, disrupting balance, negatively impacting PvP and PvE, and contradicting Mojang‚Äôs past design philosophy.

Explosion knockback is a crucial mechanic, providing both defensive and offensive utility. With stacking Blast Protection, players can completely negate knockback, leading to unintended consequences. In PvP, tactics like TNT, beds, and end crystals are weakened, as players remain stationary and unaffected by explosions. In PvE, avoiding explosion damage becomes counterintuitive, as players stay dangerously close to blast sources rather than being knocked to safety.

Additionally, this change disrupts established gameplay. Players rely on knockback for strategic movement, whether escaping a Creeper blast or using beds for Nether travel. Removing knockback makes certain tactics ineffective, frustrating both casual and competitive players.

Mojang has previously balanced enchantments to prevent overpowering mechanics. Past nerfs to Protection stacking ensured fair gameplay, yet this change contradicts that philosophy. Since Mojang has stated plans to rebalance enchantments, now is the time to address this issue. Reverting or reworking the stacking mechanic would restore balance and improve gameplay for all players.

In Minecraft, the current system of stacking Blast Protection and Knockback Reduction can create balance issues, where players can become overly resistant to explosive damage and knockback effects, leading to less challenging or engaging gameplay. Reworking or reverting these mechanics would address the potential for overpowered builds, ensure a fairer experience, and promote more diverse strategies. By adjusting how these effects stack or introducing diminishing returns, players would need to consider their defensive choices more thoughtfully, improving overall game balance and encouraging better counter-play and creativity in combat.

Why Bring Back the Old Knockback?

  • More strategic gameplay: The older knockback system rewarded player skill, allowing for more complex strategies and interactions.
  • Consistency in PvP: Players want a more predictable system that allows them to plan attacks and maneuvers better.
  • Satisfying combat: The old knockback gave combat a "feel" that made it more rewarding and fun.
  • Compatibility with the community: Many server communities and minigames have built their mechanics around the old knockback, and switching it disrupts long-established gameplay.

I will not try to shy away from the fact that this would be a change that is solely based around high end vanilla PvP. Here I will provide a more in depth explanation as to why this would be a positive change for the community.

Double Blast Protection, henceforth referred to as DBP, is a strategy that was pioneered after the 1.21 update which "fixed" a game bug with blast protection. The bug I am referring to caused Blast Protection to incorrectly calculate knockback provided by explosions. As the original poster stated, originally, Blast Protection did not negate all knockback from explosions, primarily End Crystals and Respawn Anchors. In a large majority of the players eyes, this was a healthy way that the enchantment functioned, and allowed for skillful expressions of smart positioning to dictate the flow of most fights. However as players have mechanically developed their skills, DBP has allowed for most players to simply ignore decision making and only rush their opponent with no punishment for bad position or decision making.

I personally have played PvP in this gamemode for multiple years, and believe that the community was much better off before the bug was fixed. I also dont believe that people outside the community would be worse off without the change, as few people outside of the Crystal Community even use the enchantment to the extent where they would benefit from this effect.

Please consider this when reworking or changing the enchantment, as has been planned.

Dear Mojang Team,

I hope you're well. I‚Äôm writing to express concerns about the recent update affecting Blast Protection and how it has rendered crystal PvP nearly impossible. As a dedicated player, I‚Äôve thoroughly enjoyed the strategic depth of crystal PvP, which has added excitement and skill to Minecraft‚Äôs combat.

Crystal PvP is unique because it requires players to combine tactics, positioning, and quick thinking. The use of end crystals added an additional layer of strategy, making PvP more engaging. However, the new update, which makes Blast Protection severely limit or negate the effectiveness of crystals, has undermined this aspect of the game. Many players now find crystal PvP frustrating or unplayable, as the strategy behind using crystals has been significantly reduced.

While I understand the need for balance, I feel this change was too drastic and removed an essential component of the PvP experience for many players. I believe adjusting the effectiveness of Blast Protection against crystals could restore balance without removing crystal PvP entirely. This would allow players to continue enjoying a more strategic, dynamic combat style.

I hope Mojang considers community feedback and finds a solution that ensures a balanced and enjoyable experience for all playstyles. Thank you for your time and for continuing to improve Minecraft.

Sincerely,

The old knockback system in Minecraft was known for its consistency and predictability, allowing players to anticipate the direction and force of knockback based on their attacks. This system fostered strategic gameplay, especially in PvP scenarios, where players could use knockback to their tactical advantage, like knocking opponents off ledges or into traps. The new knockback system, however, introduced changes that made trajectories less predictable and reduced combat fluidity. These alterations have impacted the balance and enjoyment of gameplay, making it harder for players to plan their actions and reducing knockback's effectiveness as a strategic tool. Many players feel the old system offered a better, more enjoyable experience and are advocating for its return to restore consistency, balance, and the fun that knockback mechanics once brought to Minecraft.

As an active Crystal PvP player, I strongly support reverting the current Blast Protection knockback stacking and bringing back the old knockback system. The previous knockback made PvP feel fast-paced, skill-based, and fun. Explosion knockback was essential for movement, combos, and quick decision-making ‚Äî all of which are now diminished.

With just two pieces of Blast Protection, players now take zero knockback from crystals. This completely removes a key aspect of Crystal PvP. Fights feel static, less intense, and less rewarding. Instead of using skillful movement to outplay your opponent, players now just tank explosions while barely moving.

The change also makes the game feel unintuitive. Explosions should move players ‚Äî that‚Äôs what makes them feel impactful. Without that, PvP becomes awkward and frustrating, especially for newer players who are still learning how to react and move.

Mojang has already shown they‚Äôre open to community feedback by reverting earlier protection nerfs. Now is the perfect time to fix this too. Please consider reverting the knockback stacking or reworking it in a way that keeps PvP movement alive.

Bring back the old knockback. Let Crystal PvP stay fun, competitive, and skillful.

Hoping Mojang takes this feedback seriously as it would hurt to lose so many tracks in Ice Boat Racing especially considering how fast the community is growing.

The effects of the bugfixes would, to be honest, be devastating for the ice boat racing community. Like stated above, an immense number of tracks throughout our history, including prized and loved tracks, would have sections or their entirety deemed unfunctional.
We need to save our ice boat racing community!

These fixes will be most apparent in the boat racing communities, breaking plenty of elements across all boat racing tracks, but it will also damage usability in communities outside of these. Individuals who have created boat racing tracks that use this bug as a common means for elements like water-elevators will have issues playing with their friends, and publicly shared tracks on sites like Planet Minecraft would have problems in the new version of the game if they use this traditional tech.

To add the the ice boat racing part:

There are minecraft events that use ice boat tracks which utilize this aswell (e.g. block wars, being first to come to mind)


This will cause many issues for them; as it will mean that they will be forced to either make completely new tracks for their event, or simpily never update, and be locked out of future combat changes and decorations, as it would break many pre-existing games in the event.

so either they spend unnecesary time building completely new maps instead of working on adding new games/ possibly delaying events. Or be stuck in an outdated version.

It is a lose-lose for these events either way!!

I also want to add to the part about removing the strafing aswell:


There is a commonly used "tech" in the parkour community where you move your camera precicely 45 degrees away from your direction of motion to gain this slight speed increase.

Meaning that, not only do many ice boat tracks get killed by the bubble column change, but so do many of the parkour maps that contain jumps that are impossible without this.

This means that not only will ice boaters likely have to stay in a outdated version to have better mechanics, but so do parkourers; killing TWO large movement communites simultaniously!!

Just to clarify some points, I had this idea a long time ago before Copper grates were even revealed and already came up with all these ideas, with the acception of the bubble column one, so now that we have a grate block in the game i figured i would suggest my idea again. I'm aware that the texture of copper grates looks small and so it makes not a lot of sense for most items to fall through but this is what we have to work with, and i feel like having this feature along side the water currents thing makes sense since it gives the block some pretty good farm and redstone applications, And items when in item form tend to have different properties than they do when placed out into the world so clearly items function a little differently in item form so this could work at a stretch. Maybe Mojang could slightly modify the blocks texture to make this mechanic make more sense but if they didn't, i wouldn't complain, Minecraft was never the most realistic or grounded game to begin with and it's not trying to be, it wears it's status as a video game on it's sleeve.

Having items being able to pass through would allow for so much new functionality with mob farms, industrial design, etc. while being a totally unique function to that block that isn't seen or is really possible by any other method.

I love this idea. I can just imagine:

  • A path going into your base while passing through a waterfall
  • Sewers
  • A protective lava fall that surrounds your whole base in the nether, with paths going outwards in all directions that you can take as soon as the lava source is closed and lava flow is below the grates 
  • If the devs let items cross: A farm grate that keeps (still alive) mobs on the other side but crops/loot/etc. cross either by fall or by water flow to be collected (to specify what OP mentioned). You could have a loot farm where mobs are in water, but can't cross the grates so they just pile up behind it, and are attacked on either side by machines so that the loot crosses the gates to be collected in a hopper. 
  • New designs for arenas 
  • Water elevators that block you from going too high
  • New designs for labyrinths
  • Closed protective walls for a fortress whose walls cross one (or multiple) river(s)
  • New designs for chimneys (In which case it would be good to let smoke pass through too)
  • (OOOH if smoke passes through) Smokey paths over fire! More than with trapdoors, which let out some smoke but blocks most of it. What if grates let all of the smoke through?
  • Suspended grate and chain paths combined with any of the above
  • Using all of the above: new possibilities for steampunk constructions üß°

• Having read the patch notes beforehand, the mace feels easy to use.

I absolutely love this new weapon! I like how it is has its own unique mechanics, but I don't think its powerful enough to be used over an axe or sword. I have a few suggestions that I think would make it more powerful. 

- Give the Mace a splash damage attack similar to the sweeping attack of the sword, but it is triggered when striking an enemy from a 5 block fall or higher. The attack will damage enemies within a small radius. Add an enchantment to expand this radius and the damage dealt with the splash damage.

- I watched a bit of PhoenixSC's stream. In the stream, he was able to 1 shot the wither from 100 or 200 blocks up (I forget which) and negate all fall damage. I think this is a good concept, but it needs to be changed. I would change it to reduce X percent of fall damage instead of 100%. I also think the maximum amount of damage should be capped, however that's much less of an issue in my opinion.

- I have not tested this yet so I do not know if this is already a feature, but I think the mace should have the ability to disable shields like the axe, but it should also have an enchantment that allows it to disable shields for longer OR deal X percent of damage through shields.

Overall, I think this is going to be one of the most unique weapons in the game, and I think these changes will help keep it from becoming obsolete in the late game, and in PvP. Thank you for taking the time to read this suggestion! I hope you will continue to add weapons with unique mechanics!

Fun idea but I worry it's not useful enough. Like, sure I could drop down on some enemy to try and deal some good damage but why not just use my bow? Why risk dying (or coming very near to it)? I don't think the risk is worth the reward.

And that's just when you intend to fall. With regards to the more common situation of accidentally falling, I still don't think this is a very useful "clutch"/"safety" item either. Why dedicate my hotbar slot to an item that might save me from fall damage but only if I'm lucky enough be landing right on top of a mob (and how often does that actually happen by accident?). Why not instead dedicate that hotbar slot to a better safety item like a water bucket, ender pearl, breeze ball, totem of undying, chorus fruit, etc?

I think some sort of "Impact" enchantment or property would prove useful as a sort of "passive fall damage negator." Like, if you fall while holding a mace with this "Impact" enchantment, it will negate your fall damage even if you don't strike a mob but it shreds the mace's durability. Just want to start off by saying, this weapon when used in conjunction with the wind charges is an AMAZING experience. This is the first time since my childhood that combat in this game has truly excited me!

Wind Charges NEED to be more accessible. With the current state of the trial chambers, wind charges are a fairly rare consumable that makes this weapon VERY impractical. I believe that the wind charges should be treated as ammo to the mace, as using the mace without the wind charges just makes it a regular weapon with a negligible perk. If I had to make any changes, I would do one of the following.

1 - For every block you fall before hitting a mob with the Mace, it adds to the amount of durability loss, because a fall from any height doing only 1 damage would ( in my opinion ) be too long lasting for a weapon that powerful, especially with how easy it may be to obtain Breeze Rods to repair it, even if the durability is only 250.

2 - Greatly reduce the amount of damage the Mace does when falling from shorter heights, as I've seen only a jump and a 3-block fall can cause enough damage to one hit most of the hostile mobs that can spawn naturally in the Overworld, and even the Nether, so the amount of damage it can do in short falls should be decreased.

If either of these are done, I would add the possibility of enchanting the weapon, perhaps modifying an existing enchantment like Knockback to increase the distance mobs standing close by are pushed when you strike, or give the Mace the ability to give damage to the enemies affected by the weapon's knockback  ...or you could make a new enchantment specifically for the Mace that can use these mechanics.

In general, I think the Mace is a great weapon, but I think a little nerf would be needed in order to make sure it's balanced for the long run.

I have three enchantment ideas for the mace:

Windstun: (Lvls 1-3)

This stuns the directly hit mob as well as the other indirectly hit mobs (aka the ones that get knocked back) What does it mean to be stunned? It means that a mob will be "dizzy" for a brief moment, not attacking the player. And for the player, it means the attack gauge bar taking longer to fill (similar to what mining fatigue does) for a brief moment! (So that you have time to escape the horde!) Scales with the level of the enchantment!

Strike: (Lvls 1-5)

Increases damage done to directly hit mob by 10% per level, and deals 10% of damage to indirectly hit mobs (this makes it easier to kill the horde, as it's no longer just eliminating them one at a time!)

Combo (Lvl 1 only)

This makes it so that if you successfully land a hit on something with the mace on your way down from a fall, you get boosted back up, so you can go in for another hit without using another wind charge. (Because let's face it, the last thing a player wants is to use up all their wind charges in one session in order to use the mace. This makes it so that if you have skill, you can land multiple blows without using your whole stash of wind charges.)

Strike and clash should be mutually exclusive.

Anyways, Thanks!

The mace was actually a very good idea, but although the appearance is not pleasant, it could have a 3D appearance that would be much better! Sorry if there are any errors in the writing as I'm using a translator, but I hope you understood the message!

I tested the item, and I'm here to give my feedback: When you test out the new weapon, jumping from various heights, killing various powerful mobs like the Warden, you think about how strong this weapon is. The problem with this is that these are controlled and very specific cases. To be able to deal extremely high damage, you must jump from a high place and manage to hit, or you will receive full fall damage.
It's true that it is possible to kill a Wither in one hit when using this item, the problem is that it would be very difficult to hit.
When used correctly, it can become a very powerful weapon, however, it's not like players are constantly jumping from high places to attack monsters, This is what can make the item forgettable, just like the trident is
My suggestion is that the base damage should be increased, or that the weapon should have an ability to launch the player a few blocks upwards, like a weaker Wind charge

Creatures that receive knockback from this item should also receive part of the damage

This is an amazing new weapon, but here are some things I think would make this weapon better:

  1. let us use the breeze charge in our offhand in BEDROCK EDITION TOO. also, for touch screen devices, there should be a button, similar the "shear" button when you hold shears next to sheep, that appears even when it is in the offhand. That would make it easier to time.

I wouldn't consider adding new enchantments, but reuse enchantments:

Knockback

  • Current Effect: Increases the knockback distance inflicted on the primary target hit by the weapon.
  • Mace Specific Effect: In addition to the regular knockback boost, this enchantment could also strengthen the AoE knockback of the mace's smash attack.

Channeling

  • Current Effect: Makes trident shoot lighting in thunderstorms. (Not applicable to maces)
  • Mace Specific Suggestion: Introduce a new channeling effect specifically for the mace. When channeling a smash attack, the mace could unleash an AoE damage burst around the impact point, dealing a percentage (e.g., 25%) of the original smash attack damage.
  • Compatibility Note: This channeling effect for the mace could be made incompatible with Fire Aspect to avoid overly powerful combinations.

Fire Aspect

  • Current Effect: Sets the target on fire after being hit with a weapon enchanted with Fire Aspect.
  • Mace Specific Effect: Instead of just the primary target, the Fire Aspect enchantment on a mace could set all entities within the AoE knockback radius on fire. This would create a fiery explosion effect with the smash attack, adding a new offensive layer to the mace.
  • Compatibility Note: Similar to Channeling, Fire Aspect with this effect could be made incompatible with Channeling to avoid having both area damage and area DoT (damage over time).

It's a good time to fix anvil repairing being so obnoxious & unfriendly to new players. Remove the incremental xp cost and "too expensive" feature, and just let players repair their weapons without needing mending. The Mace is a very fun and interesting weapon to use. It can be used in various scenarios such as with wind charges and Elytra, or simple jumping from higher terrain.

However really powerful option is that you can build up several blocks high and one shot power mobs like the Wither and Warden. There is of course a huge risk in doing so, but with items like totems, feather falling, and placing water it can reduce the risk significantly.

I wanted to look at ways to balance the Mace. Yes it is a 2.22% chance of getting a core and can't be enchanted, but I think the weapon itself still needs to be balanced.

I strongly believe however a strict damage cap is NOT the way to go. I see too possible ways that both can work well. One is too have have the additional damage dealt each block you fall decrease. Maybe a logarithmic relationship between rate of change of damage and blocks fallen, you still can do insane damage it just takes more effort.

Another idea I think can work is the more you fall the more durability the Mace looses. Falling from a height tall enough to kill a Warden should leave 75% of durability for example. Perhaps the durability can be slightly increased to account for this change.

This is a great and fun item, and I would like it to still be fun in the final release while also being balanced. It is quite the difficult task I know, but I think that it can be done and doing so would truly help make the Mace a exceptionally special addition to Minecraft
The fact that it knocks back other enemies in the surrounding area is really cool! I feel like a neat enchantment for this would be one that increases this knockback effect with each level.

The mace is quite good, with an interesting concept and a unique ability with potential. Overall, it has potential, but currently it is not a viable weapon to replace the sword or the bow. Similar to the crossbow, it has been around for years and (in 90% of cases) is inferior to the bow; similarly, the mace, as it is now, does not replace the sword. It seems more like a PvP weapon or for extremely specific cases, but with that damage and durability, and without being able to be enchanted, it is not a viable weapon today for end-game survival. Honestly, I trust (although with Mojang it can sometimes be difficult) that they will work to improve the weapon so it can compete with the sword in normal use. If they improve it, it could be a very good weapon; otherwise, it will remain in the drawer with the crossbow or the trident, which nobody uses in the day-to-day of a survival game.

And it wouldn't really be conceptually very difficult to improve the mace to make it a wonderful weapon. At the very least, it should support Unbreaking and Mending, and Looting would be quite nice because otherwise it would be quite inconsistent with the sword. And then, by making it like the sword and having, for now, one type of enchantment for damage and one type of enchantment to enhance the special ability, would be sufficient; then you can work on rarer things that would also be very good, but for now, this would be enough, I think.

Overall, I love the mace. It‚Äôs so satisfying to kill things from way up. That said, I do think there are some things that need to be changed to make it better.

Set a cap to the maximum damage you can deal from falling. One-shotting bosses is a bit much.

Make a netherite variant. With how rare this thing is, it would be an absolute tragedy to lose it in lava, the fear of which would seriously discourage people from using it in the nether and (to a lesser extent) in caves.

Not sure how I would fix it, but the fact that this would be the only weapon with a finite number of usable materials (the heavy core) is odd and, similar to the lack of a netherite variant, will discourage people from using it in any but the safest of circumstances for fear of losing it.

As others have suggested, give it a special enchantment similar to sweeping edge that makes the impact from a strike not just push nearby entities around, but actually do some damage. Also make it enchantable with the standard stuff like mending and unbreaking.

I can only see the Mace being particularly useful in PVP rather than in a singleplayer survival world, at least as it is now. In an ordinary singleplayer world, a Diamond or Netherite Sword with all the usual enchantments like Smite and Looting is fine enough, and the Mace currently feels a bit situational.

It's perfectly reasonable that you can't increase its damage through enchantments given how powerful its main ability can potentially be. However, I feel like you should still be able to at least put enchantments like unbreaking and mending on it, seeing as you only have a 2.2% chance to get a heavy core from a vault, and the actual weapon's durability isn't too great. Also I feel like you should be able to put looting on it. Ever since the Looting enchantment was added to the game, Swords are the only weapon that has ever made use of it, and having another weapon that could make use of Looting would breathe some more life into that enchantment.
This weapon could also make great use of the knockback enchantment, as it's ground-slam shockwave could push enemies even further away, making it even greater for crowd control.

I also think the Mace should be a 3D model when held, and a sprite in the inventory like the Trident. The Mace looks rather odd when held as it currently is.

The Mace is a very interesting and unique idea, but it could be so much more, and I am really looking forward to seeing what becomes of it in the near future. This update is looking fantastic overall.

A few thoughts:

I feel the mace should be buffed . It is just a reskinned diamond sword. The slam ability is cool, but it is extremely situational. I honestly do not see myself using the mace and the slam attack. I don't see myself carrying it around. The slam attack would also be really hard to effectively use in multiplayer settings. I also think the slam attack is hard to use, and the mace is useless besides the slam attack.

I say the slam attack be left as is for players with high skill to pull it off, but the mace should be more viable as a normal weapon. For bedrock edition, just simply increase the damage. For Java edition, change up the damage and cooldown to not be identical to another weapon, but in a way the damage per second is higher.

Besides just a simple damage increase, like I mentioned above, you could also do some other things that can differentiate it from other weapons. First, make it have a very big sweeping attack by default, without the sweeping edge enchantment. A higher sweeping would also make this very useful in the Trial Chambers. Second, increase its knockback.

Overall, the mace is a very cool weapon with a lot of potential, but does not justify obtaining one. I feel my suggested changes will make it more overall useful, fit with the weapon's design, and fit into vanilla Minecraft. Thank you for reading!

I do want to point out that any weapon should do extra damage when hit from a higher altitude, so it's worth adding this mechanic for other weapon types. However, the idea of ‚Äã‚Äãa shock wave is very interesting and could be related to the properties of a new creature that makes the weapon unique, and it is worth developing the idea in this direction.

I absolutely love the mace. Since it is so rare to find, difficult to use, and has such high risk, I think it is fair that its damage is uncapped. It‚Äôs fun and rewarding and isn‚Äôt too game breaking since most mobs can already be cheesed with other, typically easier / safer methods. Attack speed could be lowered since the weapon would be so heavy, which helps its base level be more distinct from a diamond sword. It should also disable shields.

For PvP, the mace may be a bit OP, especially if the player is ambushed. Instead of capping the damage I‚Äôd rather give it a soft counter: the turtle shell helmet. How it would work is similar to dog armour since they are both made from scute. It would tank 100% of the smash attack at the cost of durability. The helmet may break fairly easily, but it will save the player from being one-shot killed at the cost of being less protective in general compared to diamond / netherite. It even makes some intuitive sense since the turtle shell helmet is worn on the head and the mace attacks from above. It could also offer protection from falling anvils and dripstone.

I‚Äôd also love to see some enchantments for the mace. A channeling like enchantment would be super fun. There could also be a blowback or shockwave enchantment that damages the nearby mobs and increases their knocked back from the smash attack. Perhaps a shattering enchantments that deals increased damage to armour and shields.
As a form of protection, the tortoiseshell helmet could block the mace's attack, breaking shortly after the blow. This would be used by PVP players who did not want to fall prey to a troll attack.

A suggestion I have for the mace is that the visual design be changed from a 2d sprite to a 3d model or at least given some depth. My opinion on the sprite is that it is clean and looks great. It does a great job at conveying the materials of the mace to the player wielding it, but is not easily readable to other players. Due to the flat nature of the sprite, the mace is not easy to distinguish at certain angles and does not do a great job at conveying it's size and strength to other players. This is especially problematic for a weapon as potentially powerful as the mace. In addition, the flat nature of the design does not fit with the mace as a weapon. The other weapons in Minecraft do have flat designs, however these are all flat weapons/tools in the real world (e.g. sword, axe, shovel, trident, etc.).

By the way, to the people who want a 3D model "Like the trident", the trident isn't 3D. (Your opinion on the mace model is fine, the trident is just a bad example.)

Let me explain.

When  you pick up a trident, you get the illusion that it's a 3D model, and a uniquely shaped weapon. But it isn't. Whenever you pick up an item, it isn't a flat shape, is it? Instead, it has a pixel of depth to it. Pick up bread. A sword. An ender pearl. They all have one pixel of depth to them. So, when the trident was made, instead of making an ugly, thick texture, they opted for a one pixel thick handle and prongs. Combined with the one pixel depth, it gives the ILLUSION of being third dimension, but it's just the same as every other item.

Just something to keep in mind.

The Mace is awesome, However:

  • It needs enchantments. As it stands I would only use it in unique rare situations where i can fall and hit something, as an enchanted diamond sword is better in your average situation.
  • The mace being attained through a luck based system as the heavy core is is to hard to attain (too unreliable). I wouldn't want to bring it with me unless I had a spare in fear of losing it if I die. It should be behind a boss or mini boss you can resummon, like how you can resummon the Ender Dragon. That way it is challenging to get, but based on skill instead of luck.
  • It would look way better with a 3D model.
  • It should have a shockwave particle effect when hitting with a smash. Also, should be able to do lesser damage to surrounding mobs. (Damage could be a enchantment)

As for enchantments, there should be three, like with the crossbows and trident. They could be Splash Damage (listed above), Bounce (hitting a area at least 4x4 horizontally while jumping launches you into the air similar to a wind charge), and Absorption (killing a mob with a smash attack heals you half the mobs total health). Bounce would also fix the fact that Bedrock can't do the wind charge combo with an off hand wind charge, instead switching active slots.

Enchantments

I think there should be a few changes to this update, notably with drops.

Breeze's dropping rods don't make much sense, as there are no visible rods on it (yes another user commented this, I am just repeating it). Maybe we are able to craft two breeze charges INTO a breeze rod, or scrap the rod altogether and make the mace a drop itself from the vault, simplifying things, but also giving the artists more flexibility to design the mace. Me personally, I didn't realize that it was a heavy core as the head of the mace, because of the pixel art.

Also, about the 3D thing. Another user commented and said that technically the trident isn't 3D, simply it has a different model in your hand then the inventory sprite. I do think it would good it 3D, but it could potentially be very bulky onscreen. But I do think some way to make the edges of the model more square instead of diagonal pixels would help a lot.

Wind charges paired with the Mace are a great idea, but bedrock players don't exactly get the luxury of doing that, because of the offhand feature being exclusive to Java. Maybe this is when we fix this parity feature between both versions (banner shields came last update, that was a parity) and allow bedrock to have anything in offhand (which I'm sure the community would welcome), OR allow breeze charges in your offhand like arrows or a shield. 

A custom animation for swinging (1st and 3rd person) the mace would probably do wonders for this weapon, but also a custom cooldown.

I think that a custom longer cooldown for the Mace would make it feel heavy, like the snapshot article states, because right now it feels like an unenchanted diamond axe with a cool ability. Speaking of enchantments, I do think that unbreaking and mending should be able to applied to the Mace, but not damage enchantments. 

Maybe have a shockwave effect, even if you miss. To fix this looking weird, maybe it could only work if you are on the ground, and a custom animation could be implemented where your character slams the Mace on the ground. Also, a damage cap would be nice, and maybe the more damage = more durability taken away, up to a certain point. Don't want to go around 1 shotting enemies from 50 blocks up and then your mace breaks in 3 hits.

I think wind charges could play a bigger role with the Mace. Instead of having the wind charges in your offhand slot, just leave them in your inventory. Now, whenever you right click, your hammer quickly smashes the ground and you get boosted up, using up a wind charge. This "boost" ability has the same cooldown as if you were using a wind charge from you hand, and is separate from the normal slow attack cooldown. This will allow players to still hold a totem of undying, like in hardcore worlds (which will be in both versions soon), but also have the mace be an out-of-combat tool for maneuverability, like climbing mountains or scaling walls quickly. This would make pre-elytra traveling easier and much more fun.

I still think it's weird how it's as fast as the sword. It should be at least a bit slower, like 1.5 at mininum.

It would feel more impactful and heavier if it felt slower to use, and it would also be a bit more balanced and further differentiated from the sword.

in the newest snapshot, the mace slam behavior has been changed: "when successfully striking a target, all vertical momentum will be reset in addition to negating any accumulated fall distance"

Trying out the mace in the new snapshot, this new changed honestly feels... bad. Visually and mechanically. The mace feels like it has ZERO impact because of this. You'll be falling from a huge height, and you're about to do an awesome ground slam... and you hit the mob, and then it dies, but for some reason you get stalled in midair for a second, and ground particles fly up as if you slammed the ground... but you didn't... you hit a mob from a high place in midair. This just feels so lame. The mace felt perfect before, it truly had an impact. This new change is disappointing... Please change it back

I appreciate the array of new enchantments available for the mace, but it's worth noting the inconsistency that it can be imbued with specific enhancements to amplify damage against undead and arthropods, yet lacks a general damage augmentation like sharpness. While it's understandable that the concept of 'sharpening' a mace might seem illogical, the inclusion of specialized enchantments solely tailored to undead and arthropods appears equally perplexing.

With the new enchantments bypassing armor I feel this really seems unfun to have on survival servers. I really think full protection netherite armor should be enough to survive any hit from the mace. That or armor needs a new enchantment that heavily nerfs the mace and can stack with any of the protection variants. Even modded items that bypassed armor like the rapier from tinkers construct back in the day feel more balanced than this.
I think the wind burst enchant should do less knockback to enemies.

Love the new mace enchants & effects, the drop attack feels impactful now! And Wind Burst is so great for gameplay, it's already creating lots of video content like parkour maps & MLG combos. Good job Mojang!

But Breach enchant might be an issue, after testing in PvP we feel it's starting to powercreep sword/axe in straight non-jumping fights, and it makes armor useless. Consider capping it to Breach III (45%) instead of IV (60%).

Love how mace uses smite/bane of arthropods and NOT sharpness, it makes the former books viable. Though, BoA is still very useless. Breach in PvE is also rather useless, so adding an armored arthropod miniboss in the future will give them value.

Heavy core rarity is horrible now that it's only dropped on ominous vaults, we'd need to explore tons of chunks. For Bedrock players, we have this trend of "skipping" updates, not playing the game to save chunks for future updates. Console/mobile simply can't handle 5-10GB saves as they'll corrupt, so please don't force players to explore. I'm glad I skipped playing 1.20 as trims require exploring large chunks, but I fear I'd have to skip 1.21 as well, unless I cheat the mace in somehow. I don't mind maces being rare but I just wish the vaults/mace are farmable to make keys useful, I had hoped the chambers are a repeatable activity. Exploration is fun but the game really needs to find a way to explore without creating GBs of file sizes, such as going into temporary dimensions whose chunks can reset.
I made a full post about what i think should be remade about it: https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/25412122808205-Mace-redesign

The mace would be perfect as it is now (snapshot 24w13a) if it weren't for the looting. Please, maces and tridents need looting to be useful on a daily basis, bows and crossbows don't need it because they benefit from the looting of the sword if you have it equipped in the off-hand. But as of today, without looting, nobody would prefer a mace or a trident over a sword on a daily basis.

The mace is very overpowered. Being able to one-shot boss mobs should never be a thing, no matter how rare it is.
The idea is that there is a high-risk high-reward. However, for the majority of active players who are able to "MLG clutch" consistently, it's not high-risk at all. With the introduction of the new enchantments, this makes it even more overpowered as you don't really have to get high at all to activate the insane damage output.
Finally, wearing an Elytra makes this even more broken, since the fall damage calculation is based on height rather than velocity.

I recommend the following changes:
A - Fall Damage should be calculated by velocity, rather than by height. This caps the damage output to a certain degree.
B - Holding the mace in your hotbar/inventory should increase downwards velocity or acceleration, increasing the risk and disabling the elytra combo.
C - The mace should work by transferring fall damage to the target, but not all of it. It should start by transferring only 50% of fall damage, while still being dealt the other 50%. This could be improved via enchantments.
D - The scale of the density enchantments should be reduced, such that it's 1 damage per level per x amount of blocks.

Wind burst is very fun to play around with ‚Äî however, I think there should be something to distinguish it in terms of visuals / sound from wind charges as importantly, unlike wind charges, it does not seem to reset fall damage (unless you hit an enemy on your way down).

The "breach" enchantment makes no sense in adding it, since the density enchantment already has the function of increasing damage. I would only see sense in it if they had enchantments to resist the mace impacts

Fire Aspect should not be able to be placed on Mace. The weapon already has its own enchantments that are very powerful, and if by some miracle the enemy survives, they will still receive damage from fire attack, what makes It so OP

I think the Mace can use some counterplay for PvP in survival servers. I think when a Mace hits a shield the Mace should be out on cool down, but I think the Breach enchantment should help reduce the cool down time. Also Density and Breach should be exclusive enchantments similar to how Smite and Bane of Arthropods work.
Make a mace with density make you fall faster and take more fall damage

The mace was fine before, but with the new enchantments, it's INCREDIBLY overpowered. You can one tap players with prot 4 netherite from like 6 blocks up with a fully enchanted mace. That is not a fun combat system. On top of that, it devalues swords and axes. It feels like the mace is trying to be a replacement weapon, when it really should not. The dropping down from above idea is neat, and works well in certain situations, and that's a good thing. The mace should not be an end all be all. That is the sword's job. Breach is a neat idea, but too op. Also, the mace should have a really long cooldown, longer then the axe. I think bringing breach down to 5 or 10 percent reduction and giving it a long cooldown would make the mace a great way to start and and fights. A surprise smash and a final hit. This would integrate it well into the established combat system, without ruining the sword. The sword is good for damage, the axe disables shields, the trident is good for underwater movement, and the mace is good for one surprise smash attack.

Love the mace, it seems like a missed opportunity to not add channeling to it tho.

The shockwave is flashy and cool but not very useful and for cases with hoards smth that does AOE seems like a must.

It would allow you to feel like Thor, even if only during thunderstorms and it is an alternative use for an enchantment thats already in the game.

I think it would be ok to make it incompatible with windburst for balance.

I am liking these mace improvements, density and windburst feels good to use, and mending makes the weapon actually worth using. I wouldn't change those. It could be fun if it has channeling like thor, but maybe tridents should still have a niche over maces like riptide and loyalty.

Perhaps the sword's niche should be fire aspect and sweeping edge, that way maces axes and tridents can get looting? Looting does feel like an absolute essential and swords are often mandatory. Maybe bedrock swords can also finally have sweeping edge.

I think the mace is mostly very balanced now, and it no longer works with elytra which is nice, but perhaps we need boss mobs to not get instakilled, the bosses need a damage cap. I'd also nerf the breach enchantment just a tiny bit. Please do make the core farmable on trial spawners, it's fine if it's very rare with a 0.5% drop chance, but it must have renewability, so we can also build with heavy cores.

How about to make the mace hurt you by falling, but only 1/4 of the damage? Then less people will jump from the huge height, and enchantment "feather falling" will be more using! And also, you should nerf some enchantments for the mace, it's too imbalance, even for Terraria Calamity.

Well, now we have enchantments for the mace. Why not make it enchantable with Looting in Survival mode? We currently only have sword enchantable with Looting, and this is one of the main reasons why most players use it as a main weapon. It would be cool to motivate players to use other weapons, if not ranged then why not melee ones? You can throw trident, axe simply chops loot and is not suitable for Looting, but mace... [T-T]

Also Breach (mace is already good for PVP, so theres no reason too add such an unlogical enchantment) and Fire Aspect (Its feels just annoying for a heavy weapon and breaks PVP balance) are too OP, mace is already powerful, just add Looting instead

I say the *"Breach" enchantment* that's been added in the recent snapshot should instead deal more damage the higher the targets armor level is instead of simply negating armor levels.

*Maces* and other blunt weapons in fantasy video games are often depicted to be more effective against armored units anyway. It would be a nice niche and make the enchantment more unique Rather than something that's simply adds more damage to an already existing powerful weapon.

We need an alternate equivalent to the Mace crafted with Blaze Rods instead of Breeze Rods. It doesn't have to be a Mace, but it should be some kind of weapon to mirror it (like a spear or hammer or something).

There should be some kind of "Blunt Protection" enchantment that specializes in protecting against heavy/blunt attacks like the Mace. It could also protect against anvil damage, shovels (not that anyone would use them to attack things), and whatever other attacks could be considered "blunt."

Blunt Protection could also directly lessen the effectiveness of the "Breach" enchantment, to help balance things out a bit.

I feel like the Breach Enchantment is meant to be useful for Axes as well as Maces. They are both very similar weapons and you would normally be jumping to take criticals if you are looking to chop a Zombie's life even with armor. Axes would be good to have a shared enchantment that isn't necessarily with the Sword.

Also the Density Enchantment needs to have some drawbacks for the Maces when enchanted. The main gimmick is that the higher the level the more Fall Damage it can do when hitting a mob from fall height. With the Base Damage of the Mace unaffected, it would make this enchantment feel like it is something that you will need it as a necessity rather than a choice and is too desirable and overpowered as it is. I think the best way to balance it out is to have the Base Damage decrease as you increase the level of the enchantment. That way if you owned multiple of them, you can have a Mace that is good for combatting multiple mobs and a Mace that is good for wiping out a single mob but would be terrible in combatting. It would kinda feel like a curse, but this enchantment adds the risk-reward element that no many enchantments would have, and with this update - you need the risk-reward elements in there.
With how quick damage scales with the density enchantment, I think it should really only go up to density II at most
"Channeling" for Mace, but incompatible with "Wind Burst".

I don't like how the mace is, if allowed to pair with wind charges, effectively unusable in PVP Combat without being absurdly unfair.
In my testing, a single Wind Charge using player can oneshot a player in full diamond armor; this is absurdly powerful and means the Mace cannot really be used in a balanced PVP situation; it's just too good.
For an update with a focus on combat, it feels kind of sad that the brand new weapon, if allowed to use its intuitive combo, is simply too powerful to at all be considered fair.
If the mace isn't going to be nerfed further in survival, perhaps make it's damage ramp-up more configurable with command magic? From what I can tell, the mace's damage ramp-up is unaffected by the likes of Weakness or weapon attributes.

My suggestion to enhance the Breach enchantment on the mace is to introduce dual functionality. When a player is on solid ground and strikes an opponent, it should launch the enemy into the air. Conversely, an attack while airborne could grant temporary propulsion, enabling vertical movement. This addition would expand tactical options in the game and enrich the player experience.

As much as I love the mace and the concept of it, I think it‚Äôs too powerful by a long shot. Here‚Äôs some examples that many others have also pointed out:
-One shots any mob, aside from armored wolves, mobs holding totems, and armor stands
-Kills a player with full Protection 4 Netherite when dropping not even 20 blocks. An unarmored player won‚Äôt die if they miss their attack, but any player being attacked will. Note that this is an unenchanted mace, the height needed to kill a maxed out player will be a lot lower if you enchant it. The reward is so high with little risk
-No damage cap, unlike other things that use gravity to deal damage (anvil and dripstone)
-Slow falling does not affect the mace at all, removing risk and allows easier attacks

In my opinion, the mace needs both a damage cap and a damage reduction. Also, the fact that it negates fall damage entirely is absurd and doesn‚Äôt make sense. As other people have suggested, there are ways to fix this:
-the mace only reduces a %of fall damage
-damage cap, maybe 20 hearts to match dripstone and anvils
-damage based on how fast you‚Äôre falling, not height
-durability damage based on damage you deal
-reducing damage per block fallen
-nerf damage increase by Density enchantment
-nerf Breach enchantment‚Äôs ability to ignore armor by up to 60%

However, the other changes are far too drastic IMO, essentially mandating the usage of wind charges for acceptable damage. 

Firstly I'd like the base damage to be greatly increased, enough to two shot most mobs, greatly enhanced knockback when on the ground, as well as the ability to knockback multiple targets in its swing arc. 

Next would be to revert the mutual enchantment nerfs, only keeping Density and Breach Mutually exclusive.

Along with knocking back targets, the mace should also be able to deal damage to multiple enemies with the smash attack itself, not just from knockback and the potential fall damage from it. This is all around a really bad idea, and I almost thought it wasn't real until I saw all the comments in here of people talking like children. First off, removing the obfuscation map. While it would make things more difficult for people attempting to modify the game, it will have nowhere near the same impact as removing the pdb file. It may make things slightly more difficult, but it's by no means impossible. This is actually a quirk of the Java language. Basically, most languages will compile your code into something a machine can read and execute. Java however, compiles your code into byte-code which is close to but not quite machine readable code. When you run a Java application, Java actually compiles this byte-code down to machine code at runtime. This has the benefit that you can run Java apps on any machine that can run Java instead of needing a different compilation for each piece of hardware. If it works on Windows, it'll work on Mac or Linux with no extra steps. Native-Image would only do so much to combat this. It is not a perfect solution at all, and would create more work for the developers as they'd need to compile a different version of Minecraft for each operating system. DRM is a bad suggestion in any circumstance too. Ironically, this would make the situation worse because mod developers would be overburdened with no incentive to keep working, while cheat developers would continue to have a very clear financial incentive. Please reconsider your feedback.

WOMP WOMP that's on you. If you were subject to a port scourer, then it's your responsibility. In future, keep your server in online mode when playing and add a whitelist. If you used external connection-type mods that may have a vulnerability then that's also on you.
For the most part that last bit also has nothing to do with the main post, that's not something it would fix lol. 

Almost all of the public Java and Bedrock servers, and mods for Java and bedrock (bedrock has a very small handful of proper mods, they were just picking up as well, ironic tbh) rely on the PDB (for BE) or the Obfuscation Map (for Java) to work and modify the game. 

And this change wont improve security as much as ppl think, most servers already use anti-cheats, and you can protect personal worlds by using a whitelist. Removing this type of access is not the miracle fix people think it is.
Woah! Amazing idea kinda like what they did with Bedrock :o

Even if the Obfuscation maps are removed and it is uses DMR. Many people say it will make MineCraft much safer, but that's technically not true, using DMR and removing Obfuscation maps, won't stop hackers. If they want something they'll spend hours trying to get it. And removing the obfuscation maps has the risk of really hurting minecraft's community and popularity. Most people don't try make malicious mods, and if you download one, that's on you. You're responsible. Don't blame it on the obfuscation maps being provided. because you didn't check to make sure that the mod was completely safe, The hackers will always (And I mean ALWAYS) find a way. The average person might have more trouble, so legit modding will be greatly affected. I

agree with everyone that said to request better server anticheat. Instead of requesting the obfuscation map be removed.

Mojang: I'm sure many players will agree (and many will not), but for the sake of minecraft please keep the obfuscation maps, but instead make better anticheat. Many people love this game. And many (including me) fear that removing the obfuscation maps will only hurt MineCraft.

Ps. If you can't read code, maybe ask some ai helper to make a python script that can determine whether or not that file is safe (may or may not work.) Or determine whether or not the file is malicious.

Thank You for reading. I hope this comment will help.

Sincerely.
